topics.name: Search
topics.details: A search system is a program or feature that searches for and identifies items in collection that correspond to keywords, phrases, or characters specified by the user.

topics.name: Example
details: Search engines such as Bing generate matching results (e.g., movie title) along with contextually relevant information (e.g., showtimes) based on the user's current location and time.
An in-app search feature such as Microsoft Search in office products allows users to quickly find application specific information, from commands, help, to recently used files and more.

topics.name: Recommendation
topics.details: A recommendation system suggests content to the user that is likely to be of interest. In some cases, this is done by predicting the rating or preference a user would give to an item.

topics.name: Example
details: Playlist generators for video and music services like Netflix, YouTube and Spotify.
Product recommender services such as Amazon.
Contextual assistant services such as Meeting Insights.

topics.name: Conversational AI
topics.details: Conversational agents, or dialogue systems, interact with people through natural-language dialogue. Historically this is achieved by recognizing speech, classifying intents, and 'slot filling'.

topics.name: Example
details: Voice assistants for productivity management or home automation like Cortana, Siri, and Alexa.
Chatbots for customer support in most ecommerce websites.

topics.name: Text Prediction and Assistance
topics.details: Text prediction and writing assistants utilize machine learning to help users through various steps of the writing process, including research, grammar and tone checking, and localization.

topics.name: Example
details: Predicting the next set of words or action commands based on the user's input.
Providing corrections for spelling, grammar, and punctuation mistakes.
Making suggestions for similar words, paraphrases, and alternative expressions.

topics.name: Classification
topics.details: Text or document classification refers to the process of categorizing text into organized groups by assigning predefined labels to them.

topics.name: Example
details: Spam filters in email applications such as Microsoft Outlook.
Scheduling assistants that detect meeting appointments based on the content of email.

inputModality.instructions: Please make a selection to see more information about your primary input modality.

topics.name: Text
topics.details: Any input from keystrokes or text-bearing documents can be considered text input.

topics.name: Example
details: Search systems enable users to retrieve information by entering text queries.

topics.name: Example
details: Recommender systems enable users to explore various contents, products or services that match their behavior or preferences by entering one or more keywords.
Music playlist generators will ask onboarding users to select a few songs or genres to tailor its recommendation.
Fitness apps will ask onboarding users to answer questions about lifestyle and routine behavior to tailor its recommendation.

topics.name: Example
details: Chatbots allow users to formulate their questions by entering text and retrieve relevant information.

topics.name: Example
details: Predictive text enables efficient use of keystrokes by suggesting a set or sequence of words given some preceding text.

topics.name: Example
details: Spam filters allow email users to specify (via text) categories of email messages that they want to filter out from their inbox.

taskCard.title: Input Errors
taskCard.message: Your system will take text as its primary input modality. Here are some scenarios that you can consider including in your user testing protocol.

tasks.name: Spelling error results in wrong input
tasks.details:
Spelling mistakes are a common source of text input errors, including missing letters, accidental letter additions, swapping and replacing letters. Here are some ways to simulate spelling errors:

  • Use a word scrambler to switch the position of any two adjacent letters.
  • Use any of the four techniques to manipulate the user's utterance.
    • Truncation: removing a vowel or consonant from a word (e.g., leter instead of letter)
    • Substitution: replacing a vowel or consonant with another one in their respective position in the word (e.g., fimite instead of finite)
    • Insertion: adding an extra vowel or consonant to a word (e.g., misstake instead of mistake)
    • Swapping: switching positions between two adjacent letters (e.g., recieved instead of received)

topics.name: Speech
topics.details: Speech input is widely used in conversational assistants such as home automation systems, dictation and language translation services.

topics.name: Example
topics.details: Search systems that are integrated into voice assistants enable users to retrieve information by entering speech queries.

topics.name: Example
details: Recommender systems that are integrated into voice assistants enable users to explore relevant information by entering speech queries.
Home-based voice assistants such as Amazon Echo provide recommendations for specific recipes based on the speech query "Show me recipes for pasta."

topics.name: Example
topics.details: A voice assistant is a user interface that allows a user to complete an action or retrieve information simply by speaking a command.

taskCard.title: Input Errors
taskCard.message: Your system will take speech as its primary input modality. Here are some scenarios that you can consider including in your user testing protocol.

tasks.name: Speech recognition error results in wrong input
tasks.details:
Speech recognition is often a common source of error in technologies that rely on language intelligence. Here are some ways to simulate speech recognition errors:

  • Use an automated speech-to-text transcriber to convert user's utterance to text.
  • Use any of the four techniques to manipulate the user's utterance.
    • Truncation: removing inflected endings (e.g., "-ing", "-s", "-ed") or articles ("the")
    • Substitution: replacing utterance with a homo-phone/-nym, or words that share the same pronunciation, regardless of spelling.
    • Insertion: adding inflected endings (e.g., "-ing", "-s", "-ed")
    • Extension Splitting inflected endings ("-s") from words ("cats") to add a new word (e.g., cats -> cat sit)

tasks.name: System ignores speech input
tasks.details:
Speech recognizers can ignore a user's utterance due to a disruptive noise signal.

Simulate this error by turning off audio-visual feedback that indicates proper input registration.

tasks.name: System generates a non-response
tasks.details:
Speech recognizers can also fail to make sense of a user's utterance due to a disruptive noise signal.

Simulate this error by providing feedback to the user which indicates that the system has failed to register the user's input. For example, a system can respond with, "Sorry, I did not hear what you said."

topics.name: Action Sequence
topics.details: Action sequence is a predefined event or sequence of events that can be used to trigger a system's intelligent feature. An action sequence can be initiated by the user or the system.

topics.name: Example
topics.details: Playlist generators rely on content that the user is currently playing or a history of accessed content to recommend new content that matches their preference.

topics.name: Example
topics.details: Switching between a specific set of applications or closing an application can be classified as unique action sequences that inform ways to trigger an intelligent feature.

taskCard.title: Input Errors
taskCard.message: Your system will take action sequence as its primary input modality. Here are some scenarios that you can consider including in your user testing protocol.

tasks.name: System ignores correct action sequence
tasks.details:
Your system could potentially ignore a correct signal when it classifies a correct action sequence as being incorrect. This is also known as a false negative

Simulate this error by turning off audio-visual feedback that indicates proper input registration.

tasks.name: System registers incorrect action sequence
tasks.details:
Your system could also classify an incorrect action sequence as being correct. This is also known as a false positive.

Simulate this error by designating an incorrect action sequence, then turning on system audio-visual feedback when a user performs the incorrect action sequence.

trigger.instructions: Select a response to see more information.

topics.name: Yes
topics.details: Your system will not encounter any errors if it has a clear way of knowing when it should trigger.

topics.name: Example
topics.details: Text-based systems will typically know to trigger when the user has started entering or selecting text.

topics.name: Example
topics.details:
Speech-based systems will typically know when to begin listening to the user through its 'wake-word' invocation method. Example 'wake-words' include:

  • "Hey Cortana" by Microsoft Cortana
  • "Alexa" by Amazon Echo
  • "Ok Google" by Google Home

topics.name: Example
topics.details:
Systems that rely on action sequence will typically know to trigger when the user or system has initiated an action. Some of these actions include:

  • Switching between different screens or applications.
  • Using Geofencing to trigger a reminder for buying groceries.

taskCard.title: Trigger Errors
taskCard.message: Your system will have a clear way of knowing when to trigger.

topics.name: No
topics.details: Your system will have difficulty knowing when to trigger if it needs to rely on loosely defined user utterances or action sequences.

topics.name: Example
topics.details: Speech-based systems that do not rely on an explicit invocation method may have difficulty knowing when to trigger. For example, multiple people with similar voice profiles could unintentionally trigger the system.

topics.name: Example
topics.details: Systems that take action sequence as its primary input will sometimes have difficulty knowing when to trigger if it's unclear whether a predefined action sequence took place or not.

taskCard.title: Trigger Errors
taskCard.message:
Any uncertainty in knowing when to invoke the intelligent feature can sometimes result in triggering wrongfully, or triggering the system too early or often.

Here are some scenarios that you can consider including in your user testing protocol.

tasks.name: System triggers too early
tasks.details:
Your system can trigger too early when it has a problem perceiving an input signal.

Simulate this error by artificially inserting a short time span between the user's input and system feedback.

  1. Choose a short time span (e.g., 1 to 2 seconds) between the beginning of the user's input and system feedback that indicates receipt of input.
  2. Use this time span as a condition to trigger system feedback.

tasks.name: System triggers too often
tasks.details:
Your system can trigger too often when it has a problem perceiving an input signal.

Simulate this error by repetitively triggering system feedback after every keystroke, audio signal, or action upon user input.

delimiter.instruction: Once the system begins the activation process, it will also need to have a clear way of delimiting the user's input. Select a response to see more information.

topics.name: Yes
topics.details: Your system will not encounter any errors if it has a clear way of delimiting the user's input.

topics.name: Example
topics.details: In text-based systems, an example of a delimiter are punctuation characters, which act as separators for distinct ideas. A delimiter may also be a group of characters or words.

topics.name: Example
topics.details:
Systems that rely on action sequences usually have a clear way of knowing when to delimit the user's input. Example action sequences that are clearly delimited include:

  • Hovering over a text for 2 seconds
  • Releasing a button press after 5 seconds

topics.name: No
topics.details: Your system might be relying on loosely defined user utterances or action sequences.

topics.name: Example
topics.details:
In text-based systems, this could happen when there is uncertainty in determining whether the formulated utterance is semantically or grammatically complete. Your system might have difficulty delimiting the user's input in the following example:

  • How is the weather?
  • How is the weather in Redmond, Seattle?

topics.name: Example
topics.details:
In speech-based systems, an example of a delimiter are momentary pauses after an utterance or changes in intonation.

There is also uncertainty in determining whether the spoken utterance is semantically or grammatically complete. Your system might have difficulty delimiting the user's input in the following example:

  • How is the weather [pause] in Redmond, Seattle?

topics.name: Example
topics.details:
Writing Assistants might rely on underspecified rules for delimiting user input, such as phrasal expressions or whole sentences, to support a natural, uninterrupted writing experience. Your system might have difficulty delimiting the user's input in the following example:

  • Students should follow...
  • Students should follow these guidelines...
  • Students should follow up with their mentors...

interpretation.instructions: Select a response to see more information.

topics.name: Yes
topics.details: Multiple interpretations of the same text, acoustic properties of the speech utterance, or action sequence can exist when there is no clear signal that helps the system disambiguate similar or identical input signals.

topics.name: Example
topics.details:
In text-based systems, multiple interpretations of the same word can happen in the following ways:

  • Ontario, province of Canada; or Ontario, city in the state of California.
  • May the fifth month of the year; or may, a verb used to express possible opportunities.

topics.name: Example
topics.details:
In speech-based systems, multiple interpretations of similar sounding speech utterances can happen in the following ways:

  • Interpreting whether as weather.
  • Interpreting palate as palette, or pallet.

topics.name: Example
topics.details:
• Skipping two songs in a playlist in order to listen to the third song.
  • Skipping two songs in a playlist in order to see different recommendations for songs.

topics.name: Example
topics.details:
Multiple interpretations of the same email message can happen when certain details of the email are underspecified.

  • Meeting request on the weekend as beginning on Friday, Saturday or Sunday.
  • Meeting request for next month as exactly 29 days, 23 hours, 59 minutes and 59 seconds from the current time.

topics.name: No
topics.details: Your system will not encounter any errors if there is only one valid interpretation of the user's input.

topics.name: Example
topics.details:
Formulating highly specific queries can lead to very few or one valid interpretation(s) of the user's input. The query in the following example would only result in one valid interpretation because the day, time and location is specified:

  • How is the weather tomorrow in Seattle, Washington from 1 to 2pm?
